thread.title: Vineland football: Seymore popular among D-I programs
thread.title_full: Vineland football: Seymore popular among D-I programs

title: Vineland football: Seymore popular among D-I programs
text:
Vineland football: Seymore popular among D-I programs JOSH FRIEDMAN, @JFriedman57 7:10 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 Buy Photo Vineland's Daivon Seymour warms up before kickoff Friday night, Oct. 23 at Absegami. (Photo: Joe Lamberti/Staff Photographer) Buy Photo Story Highlights Junior rushed for 585and seven touchdowns in first five games this season Has received interest from Rutgers, Virginia Tech and West Virginia Will attend Saturday's Rutgers game vs. No. 1 Ohio State as a guest of the Scarlet Knights 57 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Tara Moseley had to resist the urge to open her grandson’s mail at first. 
When Moseley started seeing letters and brochures from colleges recruiting Vineland High School junior Daivon Seymore at the beginning of the season, she couldn’t wait to see what was inside. 
Now, less than two months later, Moseley is used to it. 
“They come every day,” she said, “so when I see one, I don’t even bother. I let him deal with it. … There’s too many.” Melton back on gridiron after mourning grandfather 
Seymore has received interest from Rutgers, Virginia Tech and West Virginia this season, just to name a few. He keeps all the correspondence in a giant Rutgers envelope on his kitchen table. 
“It’s exciting,” he said. “I always wanted to have the opportunities like I’m getting right now.” 
Seymore, who had rushed for 585 yards and scored seven touchdowns this season going into Friday's game, will be on Rutgers' campus for the second time this year on Saturday night when the Scarlet Knights host No. 1 Ohio State. He was also invited to New Brunswick when Rutgers hosted Kansas in late September. 
“It’s pretty fun,” Seymore said of his first excursion up north. “I go up there, I get to meet the coaches, I get to eat with them before the games, and then I get to go out there on the field and watch the players warm up, and I have real close seats, so I can watch the game and I get to talk to a whole bunch of students from there.” Vineland's Gonzalez moved back to city for football 
Seymore admits he’s thought about playing in front of those same fans he sat and watched the game with. 
“I watch a lot of NFL highlights, college highlights, and I could see myself doing stuff like that in college,” he said. 
So can his coach, Dan Russo. 
“Daivon is a special talent,” he said. “There’s not many 6-foot, 220-pound running backs that can do what he can, 4.4 (40-yard dash), bench press 330. He’s just a phenomenal athlete. We can’t wait to see him play somewhere in a couple years. Luckily, we still have another year with him.” 
And Seymore understands that, which is why he’s keeping the same attitude he had his first two seasons at Vineland. Vineland football: Reyes, Bokma impressing as freshmen 
“I try not to let it get to my head all the time,” he said. “I just try and take it one day at a time, worry about football, worry about school, got to get my grades up higher and higher. My grades are pretty good right now, but every day I just take it one day a time.” 
He gets plenty of help from Russo, who continues to stress his school work, and Moseley, who keeps him plenty busy at home. 
“I’m the proud grandmom, and I’m just like, yeah, you’re a football hero, but you still have to take out the trash, clean your room, rake the leaves,” she said. “You still have things you have to do. Life goes on.” Football: Zigler defined by toughness 
But Moseley does get excited. She constantly talks about Seymore when she’s at work at the New Jersey Veterans Memorial home, and her Facebook profile picture is his invitation to the Rutgers-Ohio State game. 
“I tell him it’s an honor,” she said, “but at the same time I explain to him that he’s one of the exceptions. Another exception is coming up, up and coming. You’re good, but there’s always going to be somebody that’s going to be better or fight just as hard to get where you are.” 
Seymore has taken those words to heart, Russo said. Vineland's Cephas returns to field 
“He’s a coach’s dream,” Russo said. “Great attitude, great work ethic and like I said, very humble, and that’s what we’re looking to do here. I tell the kids if you’re that good, other people talk about you, never talk about yourself. If you’re that good, people know.” 
Seymore’s ever-filling mailbox is proof of that. 
Josh Friedman; (856) 563-5257; jfriedman2@gannettnj.com 57 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://vineland.dj/1S1vW0A TOP VIDEOS
